newsitem.title: REPUBLIC OF IRELAND: Irish govt seeks to slash business taxes - report.
newsitem.headline: Irish govt seeks to slash business taxes - report.

text.p: The Irish government is aiming to slash corporation tax rates to a standard 12.5 percent by the year 2011 in a bid to sustain the country's economic and employment boom, the Irish Independent newspaper said on Thursday.
The newspaper said the existing top rate of corporation tax -- at 36 percent -- would be reduced over 14 years for all companies, banks and financial services.
In addition, a rate of 25 percent would apply to investment or "passive" income and would also be phased in by 2011. The government was expected to announce the package next week, the newspaper said.

The report said corporation tax was expected to yield more than 1.4 billion Irish pounds this year in revenue for the government. It said the government hoped the gradual move to the lower tax rate would prevent any loss of revenue.
It noted that various tax loopholes wuld also be phased out over the same period.
